s.text: (This sounds more cynical than it is; one way to so convince Congress is to speak to their sense of justice as well as to their pocketbook.)

Thus, I would think that Weisberg might be waiting a while for an "apology."
It strikes this conservative African-American as bordering on liberal racism for Jacob Weisberg to ask, as he does in this response to Watts' press secretary, if Rep.
If I'm smart, I'll want to get someone else to write Chatterbox for that time (which is legal).

Watts is a black man; a football player; a Republican; a businessman; a member of Congress; a family man (despite admitted mistakes as a teen-ager); and countless other things that have all served to mold him into a specific unique individual.
As a matter of full disclosure: I am African-American, a Republican, and I work for the Republican Party.
It's not too surprising that they would each assume prominent roles as public faces of the insurgent class.
The different treatment afforded those gentlemen indicates that, though both are African-American, they are substantively different men--physically, politically, and oratorically.
